there’s definitely a lot of luck involved here, but the backspin increases the possibility of getting lucky. to continue your golf analogy, it’s like how backspin makes it easier to stick the ball on the green. backspin effectively widens the range where the ball could hit the rim and then pop up nearly vertically and drop in (as opposed to hitting too low and bouncing back or hitting to high and bouncing right over the basket). there are two ways it helps; the first is by changing the arc of the ball while it’s in the air, the ball arcs a little higher and then drops a bit more steeply. probably the bigger factor is canceling out some of the forward momentum of the ball when it hits the rim the first time, which you can see pretty clearly in the video. without that, if it hit where it did on the rim, it looks like it would have bounced over the rim entirely. so it’s really a combination of luck and skill, or maybe “skillful luck”, since the skill helps lead to the luck.

not to be that guy, but this article reeks of someone who never actually played baseball. that’s hosmer’s ball for all the reasons you outlined. the only acceptable pop-up for a pitcher is if no one else can get to it like that awesome eddie guardado catch in foul territory.

the pitcher is only supposed to go after balls no one else can get to.  the catcher’s job on a pop is to direct traffic, and he called it as hosmer’s. if the pitcher “fucking goes” for a pop-up that is the responsibility of the hard-charging first baseman, while everyone is looking up and not around, the padres would have lost the game, a pitcher, and a first baseman.

i don’t get why so many people here are acting like the pitcher is spoiled. of the three people who can field the ball, one of them takes a whole lot more fielding practice, has a big, padded 1st baseman’s mitt, is facing the direction of the hit, and has four gold gloves. obvious choice. 
look, if there were some miscommunication and hosmer was out of position or late responding, and then maton watched it drop, then maybe you can blame the pitcher for being too timid about taking pop-ups, but that isn’t what happened here.

catchers turn around on pop ups above them because they don’t want the ball moving away from them. with the glove supinated above your head, you don’t want to be moving forward to try to catch the ball with the glove in that position. you’re likely to end up getting it in the palm and having it bounce out. it’s something catchers are taught at a very early age. spin around, find the ball, and position yourself under it accordingly. the basket catch is a possibility, but it’s not the ideal play for the catcher, especially given the height.

because of the spin on the ball, catchers are always taught to turn their back to the field when fielding pop ups because otherwise the ball is spinning away from them, making it very difficult to catch. for that reason, pop ups in fair territory are a much tougher plays than it looks like for a catcher. this was still in the range where the catcher could have made the play, but he would have needed to leave then plate with a potential play on a dropped ball too, which complicates things.
seeing someone miss an easy pop-up and hang their head in shame like that is giving me grade school ptsd.

hosmer’s ball 100%.  a pitcher is never expected to catch a pop-up on the infield, he was just being a good teammate and trying to deflect the blame off hosmer. you don’t want your catcher making that play either because the ball would be trailing away from him (that’s why he would turn around, so the ball would be coming toward him).

that’s a very difficult play, for both the first basemen and the catcher. from the catchers pov, coming out in front of the plate to catch a pop up is exponentially harder than catching one behind the plate. you do have to turn around—if you try to catch it without turning around, it’s damn near impossible to track, especially in all that gear. that’s why over the shoulder basket catches in the outfield are so impressive, and why willie mays’ catch is played on highlight reels to this day. it’s damn hard to judge a ball in the air going the same direction as you, that’s why catchers always turn around to field pop ups behind home plate. from the first basemen’s pov, you have to sprint 70ish feet on a low pop up, meaning you have to make a quick judgment call about where it’s going to land, put your head down and run to that spot, then pick your head up and find the ball. you can’t keep your head up, or you a) won’t get there in time or b) will trip and fall. it’s not as difficult a play as it is for the catcher because it’s in front of you, but it’s still a hard play.
catchers turn around to make the catch because the spin on a pop up makes it tail toward second base. it’s way easier to catch with the ball tailing toward you.
this is the result of the time-honored fallacy that pitchers can’t field and must flee the mound like a bomb is falling every time there’s an infield pop-up.

i know pitchers are told to let other infielders catch pop-ups like this, but this is the type of pop-up that a pitcher should catch since he’s in the best position to field it. you see dumb pop-ups that drop multiple times a season due to pitchers standing around doing nothing since they have zero aggression to try and make basic fielding plays. given every mlb player’s training and experience, there isn’t a good reason why a pitcher shouldn’t be able to make these types of plays, but i bet if a pitcher did try to catch a pop-up and dropped it, he’d be criticized even more than hosmer was last night.
